metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (eddy covariance system of Sidaoqiao superstation, 2020)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Sidaoqiao superstation eddy covariance system (EC) in the downstream reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2020. The site (101.1374° E, 42.0012° N) was located in the Ejina Banner in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region . The elevation is 873 m. The EC was installed at a height of 3.2 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500A) was 0.15 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1-3 (high quality), class 4-6 (good), class 7-8 (poor, better than gap filling data), class9 (rejected). In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 10% of the 30 min raw record. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. 
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy covariance method' mean in the context of data collection for surface processes?
Definition.Answer: The eddy covariance method is a data collection technique used to measure and calculate vertical turbulent fluxes within the atmosphere, commonly employed to quantify energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in ecosystem studies. It involves deploying instruments like an ultrasonic anemometer and gas analyzers to capture high-frequency wind speed, temperature, and gas concentration data, which are then processed to determine fluxes on a set interval, such as 30 minutes.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'quality evaluation of flux values' in the context of data processing for surface observations?
Definition.Answer: Quality evaluation of flux values refers to assessing the reliability and accuracy of data collected in surface observations, particularly related to energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes. This involves examining atmospheric stability, turbulence similarity characteristics, and filtering out data affected by instrument errors or environmental factors like precipitation. Flux data is categorized into quality levels to indicate the confidence in the measurements, with guidelines for acceptable quality for use in research and analysis.

Definition.Question: How is 'data archiving and sharing' defined in the context of long-term observational datasets in arid regions?
Definition.Answer: Data archiving and sharing in this context involves systematically storing and disseminating datasets collected from long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in arid regions. This process includes organizing data into accessible formats, ensuring data quality and completeness, and making data available to the research community through platforms like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center, facilitating transparency and collaboration in environmental and ecological studies.

Interpretation.Question: What patterns can be inferred from the application of eddy covariance systems in measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis–desert ecosystems, and how might these patterns inform our understanding of oasis–desert interactions?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of eddy covariance systems provides detailed insights into the energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes within oasis–desert ecosystems. These patterns help in understanding the balance and interaction between oasis and desert systems, which is crucial for maintaining ecological stability and supporting sustainable development in these areas.

Interpretation.Question: How do the data processing methods, such as frequency response correction and coordinate rotation, applied to eddy covariance data help in refining the quality of flux measurements in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Data processing methods like frequency response correction and coordinate rotation are vital in refining the quality of flux measurements. These techniques help correct for systematic errors and improve the accuracy of flux data, which is essential for reliable assessments of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in arid regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the complexity of maintaining data quality in long-term observational datasets for oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Ensuring data quality in long-term observational datasets for oasis–desert ecosystems involves addressing several factors, such as the need for continuous monitoring to capture energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange dynamics. Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it crucial to have a comprehensive understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes in oasis–desert systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: A comprehensive understanding of these exchange processes is crucial because oasis–desert systems play a significant role in the ecological and economic stability of arid regions, especially in western China where they support the majority of the population. These systems are integral to achieving carbon peaking and neutrality goals, and maintaining ecological security and sustainable development requires knowledge of their interactions and long-term stability.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for specific data processing steps, such as coordinate rotation and frequency response correction, in eddy covariance measurements?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Specific data processing steps are necessary in eddy covariance measurements to correct for various physical and instrumental limitations. Coordinate rotation is needed to align the measurement axes with the mean wind direction, while frequency response correction is applied to account for the attenuation of turbulent fluctuations by the measurement system. These steps help ensure that the derived fluxes accurately represent the true exchange rates of energy, water vapor, and carbon dioxide in the environment.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of implementing rigorous quality control measures on the reliability of data collected from eddy covariance systems in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing rigorous quality control measures ensures the reliability of data by addressing errors such as instrument malfunctions, inappropriate weather conditions, and data gaps. This leads to high-quality datasets that are crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, thereby supporting ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential implications for hydrometeorological data accuracy when integrating additional vegetation and soil parameters into datasets collected from oasis–desert areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating additional vegetation and soil parameters into hydrometeorological datasets can significantly improve the accuracy of understanding ecosystem functions. This comprehensive approach enables more precise modeling of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, contributing to a robust analysis of ecological dynamics and aiding in the pursuit of carbon neutrality and sustainability goals.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of collecting long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in oasis-desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The purpose is to understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is important to achieve carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals, support ecological security, and ensure the sustainable development of oases.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to implement stringent data processing and quality control procedures when handling datasets from oasis-desert areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to ensure the accuracy and reliability of the data collected, which is crucial for recognizing oasis-desert interactions, protecting ecological stability, and supporting socioeconomic development in these regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key steps involved in processing observational data from an eddy covariance system to ensure data quality and accuracy in arid and semi-arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The processing of observational data from an eddy covariance system involves several key steps to ensure data quality and accuracy, including outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. It also includes quality evaluation of flux values, such as atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity testing. Data is further filtered by removing erroneous data, data around precipitation events, and data with a high missing rate in the raw dataset.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can long-term observational datasets from oasis-desert systems be effectively managed and shared to support ecological security and sustainable development?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Long-term observational datasets from oasis-desert systems can be effectively managed and shared through a structured process involving data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing. This involves acquiring half-hourly turbulent flux data with systems like eddy covariance and scintillometer, and supplementing with hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil data. Ensuring data quality and proper archiving facilitates sharing through platforms such as the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.
